author: Craig Nelson
title: Deadly Blasts Hit Kabul - WSJ
text:
38 COMMENTS KABUL—In one of the deadliest days for journalists anywhere in the world, nine Afghan reporters, photographers and cameramen were among dozens of people killed in a double suicide bombing in the capital, highlighting the heavy price the media is paying covering Afghanistan’s 16-year-old war.
At least 26 people, most of them civilians, were killed and 47 were wounded when two suicide bombers, the first on a motorcycle and the other disguised as a photographer, set off their bombs during Kabul’s morning rush hour near the headquarters of the National Directorate of Intelligence, Afghanistan’s spy agency.
As police and rescue personnel converged on the area where the motorcyclist had detonated his explosives amid pedestrians streaming to work in nearby government buildings, the second attacker arrived on foot carrying a tripod and a video camera, a senior security official said. The man approached a group of journalists who had been corralled by police onto a street corner, stood for a moment and then blew himself up, the official said.
Security forces scattered for cover at the site of a suicide attack in Kabul on Monday. Photo: Massoud Hossaini/Associated Press An often independent-minded media has been one of Afghanistan’s great accomplishments since the U.S.-led invasion in 2001 that drove the Taliban from power. But more years of war between the Western-backed government and an array of insurgent groups has made Afghanistan one of the most dangerous countries for journalists, with hundreds killed.
“This is one of the bloodiest and darkest days in the history of Afghan media,” said Najib Sharifi, head of the Afghanistan Journalists Safety Committee, who confirmed the number of journalists killed in the attack.
It was also one of the deadliest days for journalists anywhere. According to Reporters Without Borders, the worst single attack on journalists occurred in the Philippines in 2009, when a private militia killed 57 people, including 32 journalists, during a political campaign on the island of Mindanao.
Within minutes of the Kabul bombings, the Taliban, which last week announced the start of its spring fighting season, warning of attacks on foreign troops and Afghan security forces, denied any involvement in it. Later, in a statement issued by its Amaq news agency, Islamic State said it had carried out the attacks.
Who, or what group, actually carried out the attack was far from certain, though.
Islamic State’s local affiliate is known to claim responsibility for some attacks in Afghanistan it doesn’t carry out, while the Taliban, the country’s largest insurgency, often denies its role in bloodshed if it deems civilian casualties too high.
Both groups, however, appear to be turning to ever more ferocious , high-profile attacks in Kabul and other Afghan cities to offset growing pressure they’re under from U.S. and Afghan government forces in the countryside.
The government of President Ashraf Ghani condemned the bombings as an attack on freedom of the press.
Hours after the Kabul bombings, an Afghan reporter for the British Broadcasting Corp., Ahmad Shah, was shot and killed in an attack in eastern Khost province, the broadcaster said, giving no other details. No one claimed responsibility.
There was bloodshed elsewhere in Afghanistan on Monday. In the southern province of Kandahar, a suicide car bomber targeted a NATO convoy in the district of Daman, killing 11 children who had rushed to the vehicles from a nearby school, local authorities said. The U.S.-led NATO force issued a statement late Monday saying eight service members, all Romanian, were wounded in the attack. No group claimed responsibility.
At the Wazir Akhbar Khan Hospital, where some of the casualties of the Kabul attacks were taken, relatives of the victims lined up to donate blood or scanned lists of the dead and wounded taped to the facade of the main building. Others vented their rage, some at the Taliban but most at the government.
Relatives, colleagues and friends of AFP chief photographer Shah Marai, who was killed in the second suicide attack, carried his coffin in his village, Guldara, a district of Kabul province, in Afghanistan on Monday. Photo: Rahmat Gul/Associated Press Outside the door of the morgue, a cement bunker in a far corner of the hospital grounds, the colleagues, cousins and brothers of Nawroz Ali Rajabi, a cameraman who had worked for local 1TV for a year at a salary of $300 a month, waited for a hospital official to release his remains so they could bury him before sunset, in accordance with Muslim tradition.
When the official finally arrived, Mr. Rajabi’s remains were pulled from one of the 12 steel drawers inside the morgue and gently laid into one of the three used plywood caskets on the ground.
When one of the men zipped open the black body bag to check the remains and the men recoiled in horror and grief at the sight of Mr. Rajabi’s swollen face, bloody and peppered with tiny, metal-inflicted puncture wounds.
Unable to contain his anger, a cousin named Ali Khan, 30, screamed, “Have you ever seen the son of a government minister or a general killed? No!” he yelled. “They’re all living abroad. It’s just poor people’s sons who are getting killed every day.”
A man who was injured in a bomb blast is taken to a hospital in Kabul on Monday. Photo: hedayatullah amid/epa-efe/rex/sh/EPA/Shutterstock The bag was zipped up and then men at each end of the casket—one with a brick, the other with a foraged stone—nailed the box shut and it was taken to an ambulance for transfer to a mosque, where Mr. Rajabi’s family waited.
Among the dead Kabul journalists was also Shah Marai, a photographer for Agence France-Presse whose loss, the agency said, was “devastating.”
A police official said Mr. Marai, the father of six children, including a 15-day-old boy, was the first journalist to arrive at the scene on Monday. He warned the photographer, he said, against getting too close to the bomb site, saying “What’s more important? Photos or your life?”
“Photos,” Mr. Marai answered.
—Preetika Rana in Hong Kong contributed to this article.
